channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: With Spies and Other Operatives, a Nation Looms Over Venezuela’s Crisis: Cuba
item.media:description: Cuba is a longtime ally of Venezuela and its biggest supporter in the region, and the government of former President Raúl Castro has issued vociferous declarations of support for President Nicolás Maduro.
item.media:credit: Sven Creutzmann/Mambo photo, via Getty Images
item.description: The island nation has provided intelligence support to Venezuela for years, helping President Nicolás Maduro suppress dissent in the military and across society.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: U.S. and Taliban Edge Toward Deal to End America’s Longest War
item.media:description: American soldiers in a village about 90 miles northeast of Kandahar, Afghanistan, in 2006.
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.description: Six days of peace talks that wrapped up Saturday were the most serious negotiations yet to make way for an American troop withdrawal and an end to the 17-year war.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Cease-Fire in Syria’s Idlib Province Is at Risk After Extremists Take Over
item.media:description: A busy street this month in Idlib, Syria. Until recently, the province was relatively stable.
item.media:credit: Muhammad Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: An Al Qaeda-linked group now dominates Idlib, which could hasten an assault on the province by the Syrian government and its Russian allies.
item.dc:creator: VIVIAN YEE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Karachi Seeks to Remake Itself, With Bulldozers Leading the Way
item.media:description: Empress Market in Karachi, Pakistan, where shops were bulldozed in November as part of a government campaign against unofficial construction.
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times
item.description: A government campaign against unofficial construction in Pakistan’s largest city is leaving hundreds of hawkers without a livelihood, but the Empress Market walls are visible from the sidewalk.
item.dc:creator: MEHER AHMAD

item.title: Ontario Has Francophones? Oui, Beaucoup, and They’re Angry
item.media:description: At the lunch counter she runs with her father inside a shopping mall in Chelmsford, Ontario, Catherine Gravelle said that many of her elderly customers speak little or no English.
item.media:credit: Tara Walton for The New York Times
item.description: It has always been a battle to live “en français” in Ontario, and the province’s French speakers are now fighting mad about plans by Premier Doug Ford to cancel a French language university.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Germany Lays Out a Path to Quit Coal by 2038
item.media:description: The cooling towers of the Joenschwalde lignite-fired power plant in Brandenburg. Germany currently gets almost a third of its energy from coal.
item.media:credit: Patrick Pleul/DPA, via Associated Press
item.description: A committee of disparate interests envisages sending billions of euros and thousands of government jobs to coal country as mines and power plants shut down.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: On Venezuela, Rubio Assumes U.S. Role of Ouster in Chief
item.media:description: Petare, a slum in Caracas, Venezuela, where violent protests have erupted challenging the legitimacy of Nicolás Maduro’s presidency.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, has become a chief policy architect for the United States in a daring and risky campaign to dislodge Venezuela’s autocratic leader from power.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and EDWARD WONG

item.title: With Hundreds Missing Following Burst Brazil Dam, a Frantic Search for Survivors
item.media:description: Rescuers searching for victims after the collapse of a dam in southeastern Brazil on Friday. They have saved 189, but hundreds remain missing.
item.media:credit: Douglas Magno/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: At least 34 people have been killed, but officials feared that many more will be found as rescue teams dig through feet of mud.
item.dc:creator: MANUELA ANDREONI and SHASTA DARLINGTON

item.title: Mexico Moves to Encourage Caravan Migrants to Stay and Work
item.media:description: Migrants in Huixtla, Mexico, trying to take a lift in a sugar cane truck during their journey toward the United States.
item.media:credit: Alexandre Meneghini/Reuters
item.description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador has streamlined the process to give humanitarian visas to migrants from Central America, drawing more toward the border with the United States.
item.dc:creator: JEFF ERNST and KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Canada’s Ambassador to China Pushed Out Over Controversy
item.media:description: The Canadian ambassador to China, John McCallum, in Sherbrooke, Quebec, earlier this month. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced the ambassador’s resignation on Saturday.
item.media:credit: Paul Chiasson/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: Canada’s ambassador to China was forced to resign following a series of diplomatic missteps that have further complicated Canada’s relations with the country.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Body of Julen Roselló, 2-Year-Old Boy Trapped in a Well, Is Found in Spain
item.media:description: Jose Roselló and Victoria Garcia, parents of the 2-year-old boy who fell in the well, took part on a vigil at the town of Totalan near Málaga, Spain.
item.media:credit: Jon Nazca/Reuters
item.description: The discovery brought a grim end to a massive search-and-rescue mission that had gripped Spain for two weeks.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: India Dispatch: In India, Gandhi’s Halo Glows Less Brightly for Hindu Right and Lower Castes
item.media:description: The final steps of Gandhi preserved in an exhibit at the Gandhi Smirti museum in New Delhi.
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.description: While Gandhi’s global influence is still enormous, in contemporary India he is no longer so awe-inspiring and his legacy is subject to criticism from across the political spectrum.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Mexico Protests U.S. Decision to Return Asylum Seekers
item.media:description: Migrants sent back because of the new American policy would likely pass though the San Ysidro border crossing, near San Diego and Tijuana, Mexico.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: The Mexican government said that it disagreed with “this unilateral measure” but that it would take in people who are applying for asylum in the United States.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED, MIRIAM JORDAN and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: The Saturday Profile: This Old Basque Soldier Expected to Die 80 Years Ago
item.media:description: José Moreno at home in Portugalete, Spain, this month. Condemned to death during the Spanish Civil War, he turned 100 in November.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: Condemned to death during the Spanish Civil War, José Moreno recently turned 100. He is recognized as the last Basque veteran of the conflict.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Bomb Attack at Philippines Cathedral Kills at Least 19
item.description: Dozens more were wounded in twin blasts in a predominantly Muslim area of the southern Philippines, where the government has been fighting Islamist separatists.
item.dc:creator: JASON GUTIERREZ

item.title: Venezuelan President Does an About-Face That Allows U.S. Diplomats to Stay
item.media:description: The American Embassy in Caracas. The United States said it will keep its diplomats in Venezuela despite their being ordered out by President Nicolás Maduro.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro drops demand for all American diplomats to leave the South American country by the end of the weekend.
item.dc:creator: ANA VANESSA HERRERO and MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Canada Letter: Your Canada Vacation Suggestions for 2019
item.description: In the spirit of The Times’s global 52 Places to Go in 2019 list, we present some travel tips from Canada Letter readers.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: ‘Individual Plaintiff’ Brought Case Against Imprisoned Navy Veteran, Iran Says
item.description: An Iranian news report deepened the mystery over why the veteran, Michael R. White, was imprisoned in Iran last July. His mother said she feared he has cancer.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Arrests in Terror Plot Raise Questions About Canada’s Refugee Embrace
item.media:description: Royal Canadian Mounted Police officers outside a house in Kingston, Ontario, where the police arrested two people.
item.media:credit: Lars Hagberg/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: The police offered few details about what they called a terrorist bomb plot, or about the two men, one a Syrian refugee, whom they said had planned it.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN and DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Within Venezuelan Military Ranks, a Struggle Over What Leader to Back
item.media:description: A defaced mural of President Nicolas Maduro in Caracas. Military leaders remain staunch supporters.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: The leadership publicly swore allegiance to the nation’s president, Nicolás Maduro, but interviews show a more complicated, ongoing conflict in the rank and file.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: White Collar Watch: Russian Lawyer at Trump Tower Meeting Is Indicted in Another Case. But Why?
item.media:description: Natalia V. Veselnitskaya, the Russian lawyer who met with Trump campaign officials in June 2016, faces obstruction of justice charges stemming from a two-year-old case.
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.description: The indictment of Natalia V. Veselnitskaya raises a question: Why would prosecutors pursue a case in which there is little likelihood of getting the defendant to the United States?
item.dc:creator: PETER J. HENNING
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Government Shutdown, Roger Stone, Ironman: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger/The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: REMY TUMIN and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Two Leaders. Two Messages. Inside the Battle for Venezuela
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro used state television to sell his message. Juan Guaidó, the opposition leader and self-declared president, took to social media. Here’s how these two leaders are trying to control the country — and the narrative.

item.title: Nigeria’s Leader Suspends Chief Justice 3 Weeks Before Vote
item.media:description: President Muhammadu Buhari, right, at a campaign rally on Monday.
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.description: The decision by President Muhammadu Buhari, who seeks a second term in the Feb. 16 vote, sent Africa’s most populous country into a constitutional crisis.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Huge Trove of Leaked Russian Documents Is Published by Transparency Advocates
item.media:description: Some leaked documents were obtained in a “hacking spree” against Russian targets accused of falsifying the account of the downing of a passenger plane in Ukraine in 2014, the group that posted them said.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Files and messages on Russia’s war in Ukraine, the business dealings of oligarchs and other issues were published online by a group called Distributed Denial of Secrets.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: New Taliban Negotiator Seen as Sign That This Time, Afghan Peace Talks Are Serious
item.media:description: American soldiers overseeing training of their Afghan counterparts in Helmand Province in 2016.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: As U.S. diplomats and Taliban officials remained locked in a fifth day of talks, the insurgents announced that a founding member would lead their delegation.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: 7 People Killed and 200 Missing in Brazil After Dam Collapses, Officials Say
item.description: A dam owned by the mining giant Vale S.A. ruptured in the town of Brumadinho, in southeastern Brazil, flooding homes and cars in sludge, and leaving scores missing, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: SHASTA DARLINGTON

item.title: 30 Writers Sign Letter Calling for European ‘Resistance’ to Populism
item.media:description: Europeans will vote for a new European Parliament in May, and a push has begun to get pro-European voters to the polls.
item.media:credit: Frederick Florin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Fearing a victory for the far right in May elections for the European Parliament, intellectuals are urging a countermovement to dispel ‘a smoke screen for neo-fascism.’
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Vodafone, One of World’s Largest Cell Carriers, Halts Buying of Huawei Gear
item.media:description: The Vodafone Group said it would temporarily stop buying Huawei equipment in Europe, the latest blow to the Chinese telecommunications giant.
item.media:credit: Daniel Leal-Olivas/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The British company said it would no longer use the Chinese telecommunications giant’s equipment in some parts of its network in Europe because of political factors.
item.dc:creator: ADAM SATARIANO

item.title: At War: The Relics of War Left Behind in an Afghan Clinic
item.description: In this week’s newsletter: A look at Ross McDonnell’s photographs of homemade prosthetics, on display in I.C.R.C.’s orthopedic clinic in eastern Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: LAUREN KATZENBERG
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross

item.title: Airstrikes in Taliban Area Kill 29 Afghans Despite Peace Talks
item.description: The Taliban blamed American bombs for the deaths of civilians in two attacks in Helmand Province. The United States military said it was investigating.
item.dc:creator: TAIMOOR SHAH and FAHIM ABED
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Taj Mahal Guards Take Up Slingshots Against Monkey Menace
item.media:description: Monkeys congregate near the Taj Mahal in Agra, India, where they often scavenge for food.
item.media:credit: Pawan Sharma/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Aggressive gangs of monkeys that threaten tourists in Agra, India, are facing a gentle crackdown.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Zuckerberg Plans to Integrate WhatsApp, Instagram and Facebook Messenger
item.media:description: The technical infrastructure of WhatsApp, Instagram and Facebook Messenger will be unified.
item.media:credit: Arun Sankar/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Facebook’s chief executive has asserted control over its sprawling divisions and mandated the social network’s messaging services be knitted together.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Greeks Approve Deal to Rename Macedonia, in Victory for the West
item.media:description: A protest outside Parliament in Athens against an agreement to rename Greece’s neighbor as the Republic of North Macedonia.
item.media:credit: Louisa Gouliamaki/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The vote by the Greek Parliament, over impassioned opposition, clears a path for the renamed North Macedonia to join the NATO alliance.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Did the Queen Just Weigh In on Brexit?
item.media:description: A speech by Queen Elizabeth on Thursday made no specific reference to Brexit, but it was widely interpreted as a careful intervention. Comments by the queen, shown in October, have long been scrutinized.
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Queen Elizabeth is supposed to remain neutral, but some saw a veiled reference to Brexit in a recent speech. Now, others want her to go further and dissolve Parliament.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Venezuela’s Opposition Leader Calls for More Protests ‘if They Dare to Kidnap Me’
item.media:description: Venezuela’s opposition leader, Juan Guaidó, speaking at a public plaza in Caracas, the capital, on Friday.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Juan Guaidó, the opposition leader who has declared himself president, said he might be arrested, as President Nicolás Maduro signaled a possible willingness for dialogue.
item.dc:creator: ANA VANESSA HERRERO and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: At War: Afghan War Casualty Report: Jan. 18-24
item.media:description: An Afghan military vehicle leaves the site of a damaged building after a Taliban assault on a training center in Wardak Province run by the Afghan intelligence agency, Jan. 21, 2019.
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: At least 90 pro-government forces and 21 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED

item.title: Across Australia, Yet Another Scorching Summer
item.media:description: A wildfire in Tasmania. The southern Australian island, usually a summer retreat for residents of the country’s Gold Coast, had 56 active wildfires as of Friday.
item.media:credit: Tasmania Parks and Wildlife Service, via Reuters
item.description: Australia’s heat waves, now an annual ordeal, have been expanding into new territory — like Tasmania, where more than 50 wildfires were burning as of Friday.
item.dc:creator: JAMIE TARABAY

item.title: U.N. Execution Expert Will Investigate Khashoggi Killing
item.description: The inquiry marks the first United Nations involvement in the case, but it falls short of the full, formal investigation demanded by Turkey.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Explosions Shake Shopping District in Changchun, China
item.description: The blasts in an underground parking lot and an apartment building in the northeastern city sent people running. At least one was killed, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Strategies: Governments Malfunction and the Markets Place Their Bets
item.media:description: The British prime minister, Theresa May, in Parliament. A Goldman Sachs report this month placed a 40 percent probability on the chance that Britain would not leave the European Union at all.
item.media:credit: UK Parliament, via Reuters
item.description: Financial markets will put a price on anything. They are trying to assess Britain’s looming exit from the European Union and the effects of political conflict in the United States, our columnist says.
item.dc:creator: JEFF SOMMER

item.title: Roger Stone, Nancy Pelosi, Venezuela: Your Friday Briefing
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: Here's what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: Businesses Are Taking Action After Brexit Warnings Go Unheeded
item.description: Companies and trade groups had implored British leaders to give them reassurances and information. They say they can’t wait any longer.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG

item.title: Everest Fraud Leads Insurers to Threaten a Boycott
item.media:description: Rescue helicopter landing pads at the airport in Lukla, Nepal, near Mount Everest. Helicopter evacuations can cost as much as $40,000, depending on how many trekkers are on board.
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.description: An elaborate scheme centered on helicopter rescues from Everest and nearby peaks has defrauded insurance companies of millions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: Venezuela, U.S. Shutdown, Alex Salmond: Your Friday Briefing
item.media:description: A defaced mural of President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela in Caracas on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: PENN BULLOCK

item.title: Echoes of the Past in Venezuela Crisis, but Heard More Lightly
item.media:description: President Nicolas Maduro on Thursday with members of the Supreme Justice Tribunal in Caracas.
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.description: The United States’ recognition of Venezuela’s opposition leader Juan Guaidó as interim president seemed to follow a pattern familiar to Latin America.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Letter 91: Australia’s Old and New Spending Spree?
item.media:description: A painting of Captain James Cook in Australia. A replica of his ship is being built, for A$6.7 million, to celebrate the 250th anniversary of his arrival.
item.media:credit: Hulton Archive/Getty Images
item.description: This week’s newsletter looks at money and priorities in the land of the long boom. Plus: Free tickets to Fringe World in Perth!
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: The Interpreter: A Short, Simple Primer on What’s Happening in Venezuela
item.media:description: Nationwide protests against the government on Wednesday were the first large-scale demonstrations since 2017.
item.media:credit: Carlos Garcia Rawlins/Reuters
item.description: Why is Venezuela in the news? What caused the crisis? What happens next?
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
